logger) Parameters Type Name Description ILogger logger | Edit this page View Source _Process(double) Called during the processing step of the main loop. Processing happens at every frame and as fast as possible, so the delta time since the previous frame is not constant. delta is in seconds. It is only called if processing is enabled, which is done automatically if this method is overridden, and can be toggled with SetProcess(bool). Processing happens in order of Godot.Node.ProcessPriority, lower priority values are called first. Nodes with the same priority are processed in tree order, or top to bottom as seen in the editor (also known as pre-order traversal). Corresponds to the Godot.Node.NotificationProcess notification in _Notification(int). Note: This method is only called if the node is present in the scene tree (i.e. if it's not an orphan). Note: delta will be larger than expected if running at a framerate lower than Godot.Engine.PhysicsTicksPerSecond / Godot.Engine.MaxPhysicsStepsPerFrame FPS. This is done to avoid "spiral of death" scenarios where performance would plummet due to an ever-increasing number of physics steps per frame. This behavior affects both _Process(double) and _PhysicsProcess(double). As a result, avoid using delta for time measurements in real-world seconds. Use the Godot.Time singleton's methods for this purpose instead, such as Godot.Time.GetTicksUsec(). sceneKey LoadSceneMode mode IProgress<float> progress Returns Type Description Task<Node> | Edit this page View Source _Process(double) Called during the processing step of the main loop. Processing happens at every frame and as fast as possible, so the delta time since the previous frame is not constant. delta is in seconds. It is only called if processing is enabled, which is done automatically if this method is overridden, and can be toggled with SetProcess(bool). Processing happens in order of Godot.Node.ProcessPriority, lower priority values are called first. Nodes with the same priority are processed in tree order, or top to bottom as seen in the editor (also known as pre-order traversal). Corresponds to the Godot.Node.NotificationProcess notification in _Notification(int). Note: This method is only called if the node is present in the scene tree (i.e. if it's not an orphan). Note: delta will be larger than expected if running at a framerate lower than Godot.Engine.PhysicsTicksPerSecond / Godot.Engine.MaxPhysicsStepsPerFrame FPS. This is done to avoid "spiral of death" scenarios where performance would plummet due to an ever-increasing number of physics steps per frame. This behavior affects both _Process(double) and _PhysicsProcess(double). As a result, avoid using delta for time measurements in real-world seconds. Use the Godot.Time singleton's methods for this purpose instead, such as Godot.Time.GetTicksUsec(). _Process(double) Called during the processing step of the main loop. Processing happens at every frame and as fast as possible, so the delta time since the previous frame is not constant. delta is in seconds. It is only called if processing is enabled, which is done automatically if this method is overridden, and can be toggled with SetProcess(bool). Processing happens in order of Godot.Node.ProcessPriority, lower priority values are called first. Nodes with the same priority are processed in tree order, or top to bottom as seen in the editor (also known as pre-order traversal). Corresponds to the Godot.Node.NotificationProcess notification in _Notification(int). Note: This method is only called if the node is present in the scene tree (i.e. if it's not an orphan). Note: delta will be larger than expected if running at a framerate lower than Godot.Engine.PhysicsTicksPerSecond / Godot.Engine.MaxPhysicsStepsPerFrame FPS. This is done to avoid "spiral of death" scenarios where performance would plummet due to an ever-increasing number of physics steps per frame. This behavior affects both _Process(double) and _PhysicsProcess(double). As a result, avoid using delta for time measurements in real-world seconds. Use the Godot.Time singleton's methods for this purpose instead, such as Godot.Time.GetTicksUsec(). Declaration public override void _Process(double delta) Parameters Type Name Description double delta Overrides Node._Process(double) | Edit this page View Source _Ready() Called when the node is "ready", i.e. when both the node and its children have entered the scene tree. If the node has children, their Godot.Node._Ready() callbacks get triggered first, and the parent node will receive the ready notification afterwards. Corresponds to the Godot.Node.NotificationReady notification in _Notification(int). See also the @onready annotation for variables. Usually used for initialization. For even earlier initialization, Godot.GodotObject.GodotObject() may be used. See also Godot.Node._EnterTree(). Note: This method may be called only once for each node. After removing a node from the scene tree and adding it again, Godot.Node._Ready() will not be called a second time. This can be bypassed by requesting another call with Godot.Node.RequestReady(), which may be called anywhere before adding the node again. docs/how-to-create-map.html.title: How To Create Stage Map | CatSweeper Documentation
docs/how-to-create-map.html.summary: How To Create Stage Map Practical Steps Creating Map Resource File Navigate to Engine File System, there is a StageMapInfo. Right click the folder and select "Create New/Resource", then select StageMapData Select Info/StageMapInfo/StageMapInfo.tres, In the inspector Create a new item in the array, assign the newly created StageMapData into the array item. Editing Map Project has include a simple StageMapCreator for custom map creation in editor Open the StageMapCreator scene at Scene/Editor/StageMapCreator.tscn, you will see Select the StageMapCreator node, Assign the StageMapData created in Create Map Resource File into Config Data/Stage Map Data Select TileMapLayer Node, Godot TileMap Editor will show up in the bottom of the editor, draw the tile in scene in the Godot way Select StageMapCreator Node, click "Save Stage Map" Button, you will check the array elements in Floor Grids to validate, assign the Map Id and you are good to go! After entering the play mode once, you can check _Export/Info/StageMapInfo/data.json to validate the StageMapResourceInfo is parsed correctly into json file. Will provide a demo video soon

index.html.title: 🎩 Cat Sweeper | CatSweeper Documentation
index.html.summary: 🎩 Cat Sweeper A Godot project template with cfEngine integrated. 📦 Overview CatSweeper is a Godot 4.4.1 game project built from cfGodotTemplate This project include Markdown documentation in the Documentation folder. For detail docs included API docs, go to Docs 🛠 Requirements Godot 4.4.1 (Mono) .NET 8 SDK Make sure to install the Mono version of Godot for C# support. 🚀 Getting Started 1. Clone the Repository git clone https://github.com/Bus-Fighter/CatSweeper.git cd CatSweeper 2. Open in Godot Launch Godot 4.4.1 (Mono) Click Import, and select the project.godot file Godot will generate the C# solution and .csproj files automatically 🎮 Project Type This project is structured as a game, using C# as the scripting language and cfEngine as the backbone for: 💡 Integration Highlights  C#-based scripting with Godot 4.4.1  Built-in cfEngine integration 🧱 Flexible foundation for prototyping and production 🧪 Running the Game Press F5 or click the Play icon in the Godot Editor. For code editing, use: Visual Studio 2022+ JetBrains Rider Any .NET-compatible IDE 📄 Exporting To export builds: Install export templates from Editor > Manage Export Templates Set up export presets via Project > Export Target any platform: Windows / macOS / Linux Android / iOS Web (HTML5) 📚 Documentation  Getting Started Guide  cfGodotEngine Built with  using Godot 4.4.1 (Mono) and .NET 8
